131.content:
This is where it all started. The 5-year mission of the Starship Enterprise is, as the series goes, "to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no man has gone before." Captain James T. Kirk, Chief Medical Officer Dr. Leonard McCoy, Science Officer Mr. Spock, and other characters find truth, peace, and justice throughout the galaxy. In the 2260s, their scientific knowledge is much greater than our own, but many types of phenomena remain as inexplicable to them as it does to us. It allows plot devices to combine the best of the science fiction and fantasy genres, and alterations of the mind and body are no exception to those plot devices. In this Interactive story, the Star Trek TOS universe of an existing episode will experience some form of change. Below are two examples which might provide a good start, since they already involve body swapping or possession. The third choice is left to the reader for other episodes for inspiration.

Choice 1: Turnabout Intruder (Season 3, Episode 24; synopsis here  ; episode here  )

In the series finale, Kirk and Dr. Janice Lester, who shared a romantic relationship with him in the past, swap bodies through the use of an ancient artifact. Dr. Lester is obsessed with becoming a Starship captain; Kirk is trapped in her body and tries to warn the crew of her intentions. The transfer has an apparent time limit, and the device itself is located in the colony on Camus II, which had been devastated by radiation exposure except for the remaining two survivors (Lester and Dr. Arthur Coleman, her unscrupulous assistant). Plot devices might include: beaming a portion of the device onto the Enterprise for analysis, what happens if the transfer doesn't wear off and Kirk and Janice do not swap back, what happens if Janice succeeds in killing Kirk in her body, subsequent body swaps on the planet surface, and so on.

Choice 2: Return to Tomorrow (Season 2, Episode 22; synopsis here  ; episode here  )

Several hundred light years beyond Federation-explored space, the Enterprise finds a destroyed planet where its only life are three pure-energy entities. They used to be humanoids, as powerful and intelligent as gods, but are now confined to sphere-shaped receptacles. They have the power to possess and exchange forms with any crewman on the ship. This leads to Kirk, Spock, and Lieutenant Commander (Doctor) Ann Mulhall being possessed by Sargon, Henoch, and Thalassa, respectively. Their stated goal is to build android bodies to live out the remainder of their existence, but the temptation of having real, physical bodies intrigues them. Plot devices might include: possession of other members on the Enterprise, body swaps between characters, continuing to build the androids, what happens if Henoch is not destroyed, and so on.
131.title: TOS

1312.content:
Captain's log, stardate 4771.2. Now that the energy entity, Sargon, and his wife, Thalassa, have departed, the Enterprise will continue its exploration into uncharted space. Starfleet has tasked us with designing a navigational module for future starships entering this sector of the galaxy. We have enough fuel and supplies for another 52 days, then we will report back to Starbase 6 for debriefing. Chief Engineer Scott has inspected the warp engines and cleared them for use. But...despite our current understanding of biology, we are unsure how to classify our departed energy-based cargo.

Kirk sits in his chair on the bridge, musing in silence at the vast expanse of stars and the black void of space on the screen in front of him. Spock gazes through the optical scanner on his workstation, the blue light illuminating his Vulcan face. Helmsmen Sulu and DeSalle monitor the Enterprise's velocity as it leaves scanning range of the planet, an empty shell stripped of its atmosphere by a devastating war waged a half million years ago. The bridge makes its usual pinging and beeping. Calm.

Kirk: Lieutenant Sulu, plot a course parallel to the class M planet and our navigational borders. Heading 313 mark 146, warp factor one.

Sulu: 313 mark 146, sir. Warp factor one.

McCoy enters the bridge. The Georgia-born country doctor strolls up to the captain and gets his attention.

McCoy: Hi, Jim. Just wanted to let you know you were right. Turns out Sargon was a pretty swell guy after all.

Kirk: You were right to doubt him... to doubt us, Bones. As Socrates would have said, 'the unexamined life is not worth living.'

McCoy: Well, I've examined all of you and your mental faculties are sound. No sign or trace of supernatural control. Still, it would have been nice to have Sargon and Thalassa stick around to share some of their information. As intelligent as they were, we could have learned quite a lot from them. I guess we've got to find things out for ourselves, don't we?

Kirk: As mankind was meant to, Bones. If all of life's answers were just... handed to us, then there would be no need to ask questions!

Spock turns around in his seat, getting up and approaching them.

Spock: I think it is wise to mention that Sargon and Thalassa may still be with us. While they did mention departing into oblivion, that might have been for our benefit.

Kirk: Any traces of elevated energy on board?

Spock: None, sir. But, recall that Henoch believed Sargon to be dead until he discovered that he had merely possessed the hull of the starship. Logically, there can be no way for us to know whether or not they have truly vanished. If Sargon has the power to disguise himself from Henoch, then he surely can hide himself from us, if he so chooses.

McCoy: What would be the point, Spock? Henoch is destroyed, Sargon and Thalassa have decided against playing God with their powers. Are you telling me that they aren't done toying with us, yet?

Spock: Regardless of their motives, Doctor, we can do nothing until they make themselves known to us again.

Kirk: Mister Spock is right. Maintain our current course. Scotty, how are those engines doing?

An intercom buzzes from Lieutenant Uhura's communications station. She toggles the switch to enable bridge-to-engineering communication.

Scott: They're purring like kittens, Captain. Dilithium crystals at 85 percent capacity, matter and anti-matter generators in perfect condition. Impulse engines on standby. Oh... and Captain?

Kirk: Yes, what is it, Scotty?

Scott: It's just... their science experiment, sir. These android body stations are taking up too much space on deck. Shall I move 'em to Auxiliary Controls or send them to recycling?

Kirk: Keep them hooked up in Auxiliary Controls for now. I have a feeling that our guests may not have checked out.

Scott: Aye, Captain. Now I can get a little breathing room without these creepy bots staring at me! Engineering bay out.

McCoy walks around Kirk's chair toward Spock. He casually runs a handheld tricorder over the First Officer, its noise humming in the background.

McCoy: It's just as I feared. You're back to your normal, Vulcan self. I've been thinking, Jim. Since we've just discovered a new planet, why not give it a name? I propose we name it Vulcan II, on account of it being barren, inhospitable, and bereft of any emotional attachment for staying there.

Kirk: You and I both know that it's the Starfleet Admiral's job to name newly discovered planets.

McCoy: Of course! What else, besides politics, are admirals good for?

Spock: They are 'good' for quite a lot, Doctor.

McCoy: By the way, Spock, for a brief period of time Sargon placed your consciousness into the body of Nurse Chapel.

Spock: That is correct.

McCoy: So what was it like? And don't tell me it was 'fascinating', I've heard that from you too many times to count!

Spock: For lack of a better word, then, intriguing. I never knew how vulnerable and weak it felt to be human. While the Nurse is in excellent physical condition, her body seemed most unfit to perform tasks that a Vulcan child can accomplish. For example, her eyesight is a perfect 20/20 to the human eye, but it is inferior to my own vision. Her hearing was also unsatisfactory when compared to my own.

McCoy: That may be well and true, but what about the other senses? We're made of flesh and blood, not cogs and wheels!

Spock: I am unsure of what you are asking, Doctor.

Kirk: Alright, gentlemen, that's enough. Continue that conversation on your own time.

McCoy: Yes, sir. I think I'm going to check out those hypo syringes that Henoch prepared. If I can analyze the formula he used to slow the body down, it might be a useful discovery to share with Starfleet. While I can't imagine, for the life of me, how it could be used on humans, it might have some other use sometime down the road.

McCoy leaves the bridge. Spock remains standing at Kirk's side. Their voices are quiet so as not to disturb the others on the bridge.

Spock: Your ancient Earth mythology is quite interesting, Captain.

Kirk: Oh? Have you been wondering about the names of our alien guests, Mister Spock?

Spock: Sargon of Akkad, sir, was king of a land your people once called 'Mesopotamia'. He organized an army, conquered city states, and ultimately unified the land. Thalassa, a Greek goddess and mother of Aphrodite, comes from the term for the sea. She was among the first of their deities to come into existence. Henoch, a modification of the Biblical name Enoch, was the father of Methuselah. He walked with God and was later taken by him.

Kirk: I'm afraid I don't fully understand. Is it the origin of the names or their significance that interests you?

Spock: Both, Captain. First, their selection of names from three of Earth's ancient mythologies -- Mesopotamian, Greek, and Christian -- suggests that they have sufficient knowledge of Earth and its development. Second, the names themselves connote a warlike attitude. For example, Sargon killed many people and subdued entire populations.

Kirk: And... you're suggesting that... we cannot trust Sargon or his story. But they were warlike in the past, they admitted that and sought repentance. Vulcans, too, were violent at one point in the past, and they moved beyond their violent tendencies.

Spock: That is correct. But we never possessed the kind of powers that Sargon, Thalassa, and perhaps Henoch still possess.

Kirk: In the Book of Genesis, it states that God killed Enoch. Sargon destroyed Henoch.

Spock: The passage states simply that Enoch was taken by God. It does not state that He destroyed him.

Kirk: I think... we might be reading into this a little, Mister Spock. We're here to find truths, not dabble in speculation.

Spock: I agree. Even so, it may be wise to inform Dr. Mulhall and place her under security watch.

Kirk: Perhaps it's better if I go talk to her myself. I don't want the crew to feel paranoid.

Spock: Paranoia, Captain?

Spock raises his eyebrow again, before turning around to resume his station. Kirk leans forward and smiles, before getting up and exiting the bridge. Spock takes over for Kirk, replacing him at the chair.
1312.title: Return to Tomorrow

choices: Kirk is interrupted by a red alert and the ship trembling.
13121.content:
Dr. Ann Mulhall is in her private quarters on Deck 3F, room 67, studying from a series of astrobiological tapes on her computer screen. On her desk is a digital clipboard, where she is occasionally ticking off pieces of information with a laser pen. She is dressed in a red uniform with a Starfleet brooch fastened near the neckline above her breasts. She wears a headband that pulls the bangs out of her eyes. Her straight hair covers the ears and extends down the back of her neck and shoulders. Her legs, encased in stockings and black dress boots, are crossed underneath the desk. Her eyes are bright and piercing. Her voice is unintentionally sultry. She hears a knock at the door. It is Captain Kirk.

Mulhall: Come in. Oh, hello again, Captain Kirk.

Kirk: Dr. Mulhall. I hope... I am not interrupting you right now.

Mulhall: Not at all, Captain. I've been studying some Federation record tapes to check for past encounters with pure-energy beings. So far, any description I've found hasn't matched what we discovered on that planet. They were a unique species, sir. Possibly requiring a new type of quadronomial nomenclature for classification.

Kirk walks slowly toward Mulhall, scanning the room for her various articles and personal items. She has a computer bank, three or four digital posters of news releases from Starfleet, and a vanity table with various types of makeup, perfumes, and cosmetics. Her bed is neat and tidy. There are no stray clothes on the floor, as everything is well placed and accounted for. Aside from these things, the room is mostly empty, as if it had not been fully lived in.

Kirk: Do you know what was the first thing I noticed about you? Your sleeve braid. The double-gold-bar designation means you're a lieutenant commander, and I would have seen that on the ship before if you weren't so new.

Mulhall: A very good first observation, Captain. Many men notice other things about me first.

Kirk: I am not like many men. I'm a starship captain, it's my duty to familiarize myself with every person on board the Enterprise, and that goes double for commissioned officers.

Mulhall: I see.

Kirk: I wasn't aware that my ship had another lieutenant commander aboard. It's a pleasant surprise, but a surprise nevertheless.

Mulhall: That is because I am here on a temporary assignment en route to Starbase 6, Captain. I came aboard the Enterprise on stardate 4220.3, during your rendezvous at Miller's Outpost. The USS Lexington is in need of a commanding science officer, and I understand we are to meet them there in less than 2 months.

Kirk: And they will be lucky to receive such a talented officer. The way you approached uncertainty in the field was admirable. And your dedication to helping the alien species showed a kind of courage that goes beyond many others.

Mulhall: Why, thank you, Mister Kirk.

Kirk: You are the highest-ranking woman aboard the ship. Is there any way I can persuade you to remain with us instead of going over to the Lexington?

Mulhall: It seems unlikely at this point. We all have to follow orders, and Starfleet Command would wonder why one of its ships has two commissioned science officers and the other has none at all. Your Mister Spock is well known throughout the Federation. He is better equipped to serve aboard the Enterprise than I.

Kirk: Yes, he is a good man.

Mulhall: So are you, sir.

Kirk stands over Mulhall, placing his hands on her shoulders. She is interrupted from reading the telescreen, as she looks up at the captain in curiosity. He has been reading her astrobiology notes over her shoulder. Or is he?

Kirk: I've come here to caution you about the alien species. Mister Spock and I have talked it over, and we aren't sure whether or not Sargon and Thalassa have really disappeared.

Mulhall: But you heard what they said on the bridge earlier? They decided to join the rest of their deceased civilization in oblivion.

Kirk: I know, I said the same thing to Spock. But with their powers, their... ability to cloak themselves from detection, it is possible they are still around here. Have you seen or heard anyone behaving in a strange manner recently?

Mulhall: No sir, I have not. But I'll be on the lookout and report the instant I get news of something.

Kirk: Thank you, Dr. Mulhall.

He begins to leave, then turns around.

Kirk: Doctor... Mulhall. Your... doctorate is in astrobiology. Why, then, are you staffed in our operations department? A better post in the meantime should be the sciences department.

Mulhall: I was wondering the same thing. I've submitted a request for change of duty, but I have not yet heard back from Yeoman Rand, who I understand is in charge of staffing aboard the ship.

Kirk: I'll see to it myself. Continue your research under advisement, Ann.

Mulhall: Yes, Captain.

Kirk leaves out the whooshing doors of Mulhall's private quarters. She resumes examining her tapes, pausing to look toward the door again.
13121.title: Kirk visits Ann and cautions her to stay alert.

1322.content: What happens in this version of the episode?
1322.title: Lonely Among Us

13221.content:
After searching around the cloud for Captain Picard's energy pattern for a while, Worf suddenly registers something on his panels.

"Sir! On my sensor controls...".
"Something's here. I can feel it!" Deanna Troi confirms.
"Just as before! Going to you first, Worf..." Data realizes.

"Something crazy on my viewer circuits..." Geordi LaForge suddenly interjects. On this, Commander Riker leaps towards the helmsman's console.

On it, a blue "P" letter formed shape.

http://images4.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20...

"P for Picard!" Riker suddenly comes to his feet!

"He's in the ship's circuitry! Come to the Transporter Room. Please! There might be a way, sir! Hurry!" Data speaks up and heads of to the turbolift.

***

Shortly afterwards Data, Riker and Troi enter the transporter room.

"This is a wild theory Data!" Riker confronts him. "I knew we had to have the captain's physical pattern here, he was the last one beamed out." the android replies.

"Is what you're thinking possible?". "Unknown at this time, sir. I hope the captain remembers his pattern is here." Data says while modifying the transporter's control panel.
"If he has, his energy has moved into the transporter relays by now...". "Wish we had some sign he's there. We've no choice but to risk it." Riker orders. "Energizing, sir!" Data says, and all eyes on the room watch the transporter platform anxiously.

The transporter effect builds slowly, a bit unevenly... then firms up! What materializes is ...
13221.title: "P" is for Picard?

132211.content: ... someone from Wesley Crusher's private picture archives?
132211.title: Not Picard but human!

1322111.content:
Finally the shimmering sensation of the transporter beam stops, but who stands on the platform is not Captain Jean-Luc Picard. Instead, a young woman with blonde hair dressed in a red starfleet uniform stands on there.

http://images.buycostumes.com/mgen/merch...
1322111.title: Yes

choices: The woman awakens in Sick bay.
13221112.content:
The mysterious young lieutenant that stood on Picard's transporter pad lets out a small groan as she collapses to the deck unconcious, the tight hair band that kept her hair in a bun snapping and sending the long blone hair in all directions. The rest of the crew rushes to her aid, only to find her unresponsive.

"Damnit, something went wrong! Riker to sick bay, medical emergency!" Riker curses as her checks for lifesigns. "Good, there's still a pulse..."
_______________________

"Do we know what happened, Data?" The first officer, now acting captain of the Enterprise, asked as he and the android watched as Dr. Crusher began administering a stimulant to wake the now female Picard up.

"I am not sure, sir. I can only postulate that the transportation of the captain's energy pattern from the ship's system may have been altered in some way by the energy beings. If I may, I would like to begin my investigation into the ship's internal energy grid as soon as possible." The android responded, his tone neutral, although those familiar with the android knew that he would be just as concerned for Picard as the rest of the crew.

"Alright, do it, but keep me informed. I want progress reports every thirty minutes." Riker ordered as Dr. Crusher began shutting down her treatment tools.

"Aye sir." Data replied before exiting the sick bay. Riker watched him leave before turning to face the doctor.

"Well, Beverly? Is he alright?" This prompted a short chuckle from Beverly, breaking her stern demeanor for a short second.

"I wouldn't exactly use the word 'he' right now, but yes, the patient is fine, just suffering from long term exhaustion. I've administered a stimulant that will keep his body working properly while his brain gets the rest it deserves. I'll keep the captain here for observation, and I'll contact you as soon as he wakes up"

Riker frowned at being told to delay the debriefing and correction of his friend’s form. Until then, he resigned him to being acting captain and would have to let his other officers attend to this matter, he still had the Selay and Antican delegates to deal with.

“Good work doctor. You contact me the moment he wakes up, we’ll need a debriefing and hopefully Data will have found a solution to…this. Until then, I’m acting captain.” Riker ordered, leaving the doctor to her work as he headed for the bridge.

“Yes sir. And Will, don’t worry, all Jean-Luc needs is a bit of rest, he’ll be perfectly fine.”

“While I appreciate the optimism Beverly, I’ll be more at ease when he’s back to normal.”
13221112.title: She collapses immediately

132211121.content:
Night watch.

The long hours that passes as night for many of the ship’s crew, the lonesome period where nothing happens and the company you keep tend to be solitary beings intent of their work. Mostly junior officers, the ‘third watch’ is when the Enterprise is the most vulnerable to misfortune, with most of it’s ranking officers asleep or otherwise indisposed.

Dr. Beverly Crusher had long since left Sick Bay, her final check up of the woman that had appeared in Jean-Luc Picard’s place having responded perfectly to the small doses of stimulants to keep her body from fatigue collapse, and was no capable of resting without any such precautions. Satisfied with her work, and confident that Picard would still be sleeping by the time she returned to duty, Beverly had left Sick Bay under the care of Alyssa Ogawa, her chief nurse.

Things were proceeding smoothly, no major accidents, the VIP patient still sleeping comfortably in the medical lounger on the far wall. Indeed, aside from the routine of check up rounds across the small deck, the present staff had nothing to do but wait for something to happen.

Though there is a reason why they say ‘be careful what you wish for’.

The muted silence of Sickbay was ended with a loud groan, the ruffle of sheets and a loud thud as something hit the floor near the darkened area of the medical lounger. The staff shared a look of surprise before rushing over. Nurse Ogawa reached the woman first and knelt beside her, tri-corder in hand as she scanned her grumbling patient as she tried to pull herself into a sitting position.

“Ugh, where am I?” The woman asked as she brushed her long blond hair out of her jade green eyes. “What happened?”

“You’re in Sickbay, sir, being treated for heavy fatigue after being rematerialized. Don’t be alarmed, sir, but your body is not the same as you remember it being. There was a accident that Lieutenant Data is looking into fixing as we speak” Ogawa said in a calm voice that she had learnt from years of working in a medical environment, the way of speaking to avoid alarming the patient.

“What?!” The woman yelled, scrambling to her feet as she began feeling herself, her breasts, the curvature of her lower body, the shape of her face and length of her hair. Her frantic movements became normal as everything seemed to be as how she remembered it. She fixed Ogawa with a strange look, “Are you sure you’re qualified? There’s nothing wrong with my body, is the same as it’s always been!”

The three medical personnel stood in shock as the blond woman fixed them all with a suspicious stare, until Nurse Ogawa decided to page Dr. Crusher with a unpleasant surprise.
132211121.title: Awakening.

1322111212.content:
“I keep telling you, my name is Ariel Bachmann, Lieutenant, Command Division, USS Enterprise NCC-1701-D! I’m a flight controller! The last thing I remember was being ordered to set course for Earth before waking up here getting scared half to death because your staff made me think I had been mutilated!”

The woman who now identified herself as Ariel Bachmann was irate, pacing the small length of Dr. Crusher’s office after the latter had been summoned to Sickbay. It was very much a surprise when she entered the medical ward to find the woman she had thought was captain Picard being very rude to her staff and disturbing her other patients, as well as herself.

“I’m sorry, but there’s no record of anyone on this ship under that name! We are transporting the Selay and Antican delegates to the planet Parliame-“ Crusher began.

“-For the possibility of easing hostilities between their races in the hopes of joining the Federation! I know the mission! And just because I’m not in the ships logs doesn’t mean anything! Someone could have tampered with them!”

“You are Jean-Luc Picard. We had a unusual encounter with a alien being in the Beta Renner system and you were converted to energy to save the ship. We barely managed to you by letting you merge with the ship’s energy grid and then pulled your energy pattern through the transporter for rematerialization. I’m sorry, Ariel, but you don’t exist.”

The two women stared at each other, Dr. Crusher with a look of pity in her eyes and concern, searching for any sign of the man she had known for years in those jade eyes that were staring heated daggers at her.

“No. My name is Ariel Bachmann, lieutenant, Command Division, USS Enterprise NCC-1701-D. Whoever this Jean-Luc is, I’ve never heard of him, and I damn well know I exist!” Ariel said, her voice hard as titanium, giving the doctor one last glare before storming from the office and Sickbay.

Beverly jumped to her feet, rounding the desk as she slapped the com-badge on her uniform. “Dr. Crusher to Bridge, I need a security team to Sickbay, we’ve got a patient who just bolted out into the ship”

“Copy Sickbay, Lieutenant Worf is on the way.”

And here I thought this was going to be a quiet night…Crusher thought to herself.
1322111212.title: Confrontation

13221112121.content:
Ariel stormed out of Sickbay enraged, insulted, and very afraid. She knew she existed, she remembered everything, her parents, growing up on in San Francisco, attending Starfleet and getting assigned to the Enterprise. She remembered everything about her life up until twelve hours ago when she just remembered feeling horribly tired at her station and the feeling of falling before waking up in Sickbay! But if the ship logs said she wasn’t a member of the crew…

“Computer, where are the quarters for Lieutenant Ariel Bachmann?” The officer asked, the growing dread in her voice betraying her confident stride. Ariel knew where she lived, but she had to check…

“There are no quarters assigned to an officer with that name” Came the cold voice of the computer, the emotionless tone feeling like a knife to Ariel’s heart. She stopped dead in her tracks.

“Confirm occupancy of quarters in Section 6, cabin 17” She whispered just high enough to be heard, her confidant stride slowing with every step.

“Confirmed. Cabin is currently unassigned pending crew replacement.”

“So maybe I’m just not on the crew roster? Computer, confirm presence of a Lieutenant Ariel Bachmann, Command Division onboard the Enterprise!” The horrible feeling of truth was closing in all around her, threatening to crush her.

“There is no officer by that name currently stationed onboard the Enterprise”

The computer’s words hit her like a punch to the stomach. Ariel felt like she was collapsing from within as she fell against the corridor wall, her knees collapsing as the computer denied her very life. As she sank to the floor, tears welling in her eyes at the thought of her entire existence being nothing more than a cruel lie, the security team rounded the corner, phasers drawn.

The sight destroyed what was left of her emotional wall, and Ariel began sobbing, her hands grasping the wild mane of blond hair that she always remembered having and loving, despite the effort required to keep it in the bun that Starfleet protocol required. She was real! Why was everything denying her existence when she was right there!

The security team slowed to a stop, and the large Klingon leading them exchanged uncertain looks with the rest of his team, unsure of how to proceed.

Ariel barely heard the voice of the doctor as she caught up with them, “Worf stand down. We’ve got to get this woman to Deanna right away, something has gone terribly wrong”
13221112121.title: Confirmation of Non-Existence

132211121211.content:
“My interview with Ariel suggests that she really believes who she is. There’s no hint of Picard ever existing to her. She can recall most of her life in detail, she’s had lovers, friends, a family, a career in Starfleet, and she’s absolutely terrified that none of them will remember her.”

The conference room was sullen, the command staff exchanging looks of concern, confusion as the ship’s counselor gave her report after analyzing the woman they had all thought was their captain, now turned lieutenant with a memory of a different life.

“Could this just be a symptom, maybe something like the brain just trying to reorganize itself after the traumatic experience of being converted to sentient energy?” Riker asked, his posture stiff and rigid in the seat at the head of the table. Picard’s seat.

“No, her brain scans are perfectly healthy. The ones I took before she woke up indicated nothing out of the ordinary and the single scan that Nurse Ogawa was able to do implied a heightened state of activity, but nothing aside from what’s normal to waking up somewhere other than you remember falling asleep” Dr. Crusher replied, dashing that particular line of speculation into nothingness.

“Then there has to be a reason why Picard’s energy signature would just change not only his form, but his mind from a male captain with years of experience under his belt into a woman who is only a few years out of the Academy! Data, have you discovered anything at all, any way to change her back?”

“I am afraid I have not, sir. Due to the very large amount of energy the Enterprise uses, tracing the pathways that the captain may have used to communicate with us is almost impossible. The patterns were almost completely removed by the time I had accessed the energy grid and even the few that I could find were random dead ends.” The android replied, his face and voice still the neutral tone of a machine, but there was a hint of sadness in his facial movements.

“What about his backup transporter pattern? Couldn’t we just dematerialize the captain’s current form and then replace it with his backup? It’s been done before” Geordi La Forge said, his engineer mind already hard at work at trying to solve the problem.

“That would just leave us with problem. She’s just be a woman in her early twenties in the body of a much older man. The problem isn’t with her physical body, those are easily corrected, the problem is with her mental state, and not even now can all Starfleet Medical, do we have the technology to completely rewrite the mind” Dr. Crusher spoke, defeating the one promising idea the crew had for restoring their beloved captain. The officers were silent for a moment.

“Worf thinks that, should a alternative solution not be found, that we should grant her a mercy death. He feels that it would be better to honor the memory of the captain than let it be sullied by a unproven anomaly” Natasha Yar spoke up, her sullen tone and sheer audacity of the proposal sending a look of horror across the faces of her friends and fellow officers.

“Lieutenant Yar, that is the most disrespectful thing I’ve ever heard on any starship I’ve served on and goes completely against the traditions of Starfleet. I have half a mind to remove you AND Worf from duty until you re-educate yourselves on just what this organization is about! Riker spat out, rising from his chair as the suggestion went against everything he stood for, not only as a officer but as a human.

“I think what we’re all forgetting is that to her, Ariel is who she’s ever been. We may just have to accept the fact that captain Picard may, for all intents and purposes, be gone. I know it may be hard, but even if we had a solution, I’m sure that Ariel would refuse to take part in it. To her, it would be suicide, the very elimination of her soul to bring back a man that she’s never known or served under.” Deanna quickly spoke up hoping to defuse the situation and bring the truth out for everyone to see.

“Deanna surely she can see that she’s not real-“

“But she is real.. From my interview it’s readily apparent that Ariel is determined to make something of her life, even if she isn’t supposed to exist. She exists now, as a fully mature adult with memories of a life that was real to her. There is no memory of captain Picard and the only trace of something not being right to her is not being able to recall who is the captain of the Enterprise. She can name everyone that serves on her shift and even the exact coordinates that were laid in for the planet Parliament. Ariel is a real person, Will, and I think we may all just have to get used to her being as such.”

Silence fell across the conference room while the stars hung outside, glittering in the deep black of space like millions of candles burning for the lost captain Picard.

“I’m afraid I have to agree, commander. While she’s an anomaly created by this whole strange encounter, I can’t authorize what would be a forced euthanization on a perfectly healthy person simply because she doesn’t think the way we want her to. Until a solution can be found to restore Jean-Luc without harming Ariel, I’m asserting my authority as Chief Medical Officer.” Dr. Crusher said, the sadness in her voice apparent, but underlined with the intensity that she had shown towards all of her patients.

“Well then, I guess that just leaves us with the decision on whether or not we should set up a memorial service for the greatest captain I ever served with, and what we should do with the woman.” Acting captain Riker said, he voice cold and hard as the truth and reality of the situation sank in. “Alright, we’ll finish the mission to Parliament, and then contact Command for further orders. Until then, I want this Ariel to begin integrating with the crew and working her into the shift rotations. Mr. Data, you’re now my first officer, but you will continue to look for alternate solutions to restoring captain Picard. Dismissed.”
132211121211.title: The Debrief

choices: Wait, why are they headed to the Neutral Zone?
1322111212111.content:
“Lieutenant Bachmann!”

Ariel flinched at the sound of captain Rikers voice from behind her. In the month since her ‘birth’, the lieutenant had quickly learned that the former jovial officer was still not at terms with her existing instead of his captain and friend, Jean-Luc Picard. She was trying to be a good officer and had, in the interest of integrating more easily with the crew, read the man’s dossier. Ariel had been highly impressed at the man’s service history, but the foray had only left her in a deepening depression as his record ended with: Killed in Action.

People expected more from her than what she was trained to give. Sure, she proved that she was a competent helmsman and had earned her place without having to go before a Starfleet board of inquiry to prove that she was still capable of performing her duties, but the expectations of Picard were extrememly hard for her to live up to. The senior officers had looked at her for answers she couldn’t give, the growing number of crewmen who knew her for who she used to be gave her a mixture of pity, respect, disdain and outright hostility, even people that she remembered being friends with had openly mocked her when she had tried to ‘re-introduce’ herself in Ten Forward.

“Yes, sir?” Ariel replied to the captain, swiveling around to look at the scowling, beared man that was flagged by Data and Deanna in the three large chairs. A chance glance at the disapproving look of Tasha Yar made Ariel curl her toes to keep from visibly flinching.

“Plot a course for the Neutral Zone. Warp seven.” Riker growled.

“Aye sir, plotting now. Neutral Zone, warp seven” she replied, spinning around to face her station, her manicured fingers dancing over the LCARS screen as she laid in the precise coordinates for the warp jump. “plotted, sir”

She couldn’t see captain’s habitual hand movement that he had picked up since her ‘birth’, but she knew he was about to make it. During one of her sessions she had asked Deanna about it, and the Betazoid had replied simply, “It’s his way of keeping captain Picard alive”.

“Engage”

“It’s been a month and I’m still the outcast. I’m just a member of the crew, I don’t expect special treatment, but I’m tired of always being made to feel as if I’m not sentient!” Ariel sighed as she sat on the couch in Deanna’s office, another session underway before heading back to the quarters that were now hers (and had always been, to Ariel). “And even from you, it’s this undercurrent of pity that I don’t want.”



Deanna’s face contorted into a frown at that, but she attempted to replace it with her impassive look. “I’m sorry Ariel, but your situation, I can’t help but feel sorry for you. You’ve got a tough road ahead and it’s only begun. It will get better but right now captain Riker and most of the staff are grieving for an officer they knew and loved. Riker will come around once he’s accepted you-“

“And how long will that take? The Riker I remember was easy to get along with and made serving not only an honor, but enjoyable! Hell I remember drinking with im in Ten Forward!”

“But that’s a reality that-“

“Right, that never happened. Just like everything else in my life…” Ariel stood up, feeling the anger she’d been repressing for a month rising to the surface. “Deanna, it’s been fun, but I think I’ll find me own answers instead of spending my off duty time being reminded of why people hate me.” The lieutenant hurried to the door, taking a little satisfaction in the alarmed look on the counselor’s face. “Thanks” She said curtly, and disappeared into the corridor.
1322111212111.title: Integration

13221112121111.content:
Ariel had no direction, she just followed her feet. A listless soul stranded between what had to be a cruel purgatory of having not existed before last month and having a whole lifetime of memories she could clearly recall. The curious faces of other Starfleet officers and personnel were just a blur as the tall blonde beauty that had been their former captain marched through the halls of the Enterprise.

Eventually, Ariel found herself standing in one of the holodecks, surrounded by the dizzying grid of bright yellow on black plating that was covered in holoprojectors so small she’d never be able to see them weave whatever fantasy she could think of to escape her torment.

“Computer” Ariel called and received the typical chirp of acknowledgement, “Take me to Risa. One of the surf clubs on the beaches. Make the tide challenging but doable”

In an instant the grid vanished, and Ariel could see a endless expanse of tropical blue-green ocean, with large breakers curling in the distance and slamming back into the ocean in a cascade of sound and spray. Warm, comfortable and soothing air whisked across her now nearly bare shoulders and back and making her shiver in the revealing wetsuit as a classic Earth-style surfboard materialized in her right hand.

“Right” Bachmann said with a grin, “I might not be supposed to exist, but if these memories of mine taught me anything, it’s that nothing feels better than a surf session!”

Two holograms, a male and female, both human, sauntered over to Ariel, surfboards in hand. “Hey, Sheila!” the male cried out with a accent belonging to someone of Austrailian descent. “Surf’s not gonna wait forever love, what say we head out and catch a few before the beach party gets going?”
With a grin of shining white teeth, Ariel tucked her surfboard under her arm.

“I thought you’d never ask.”

The trio raced towards the water, Ariel grinning ear to ear at the prospect of finally working some of this aggression out her way, and not that prissy counselor’s way when the surprise sound of doors whisking open caused her to pause in mid-stride to look back at the holodeck’s entrance, ignoring the two simulated beings as they splashed into the surf and began swimming out to sea.

Ariel’s eyes locked on the intruder, and her already simmering temper was both enflamed and extringuished as Captain Riker stood there, a shocked look on his bearded face.

The simulated waves continued to crash as the two Starfleet personnel stared at each other in unsure silence.
13221112121111.title: On Simulated Seas

choices: The two enjoy a afternoon of sand, surf, and sun.
Competition brings out the worst in them.
132211121211112.content:
William Riker couldn’t believe his luck. Finally getting a moment of downtime where his presence was not required somewhere on the enterprise, and all of the holodecks were either in use or down for repairs. Simply having nothing available didn’t mean he couldn’t look, though. That was at least on of the perks of being captain. If he was lucky, maybe Worf would be having some crazy combat simulation going and he could join in. It had been a hell of a month, and Riker found himself looking forward to the chance to spend some time with one of his senior officers now that he had too many new responsibilities to attend the weekly poker game or the Klingon’s training classes.

The new captain was disappointed, however. Most of the in-use holodecks were nothing interesting. Two romantic dinners, a play, a field trip of children walking through a simulated Smithsonian on Earth and other banal activities that Riker had no interest or right to join. That left just one more, and Riker steeled himself for something that was either boring, or crossing the ground between ‘captain’s right’s’ and being downright nosy.

The door to the final holodeck whisked open, and the captain was greeted to the rolling of waves, the sound of seagulls cawing in the wind, and the backside of a tall, blonde beauty wrapped in a red wetsuit, surfboard in hand and already glistening with sea-spray as she followed two holograms into the artificial sea. Riker felt a stirring in him as he admired the woman, and as she turned around, that stirring suddenly became a tight knot in his stomach.

It was Lt. Bachmann.

The two officers stared at each other, Ariel’s blue eyes locked with his own, almost unblinking as she was sprayed with holographic water, and as artificial wind tossed her normally tightly bound long blond hair around like a treetop full of leaves on a windy day.

Crash. The captain’s heart beat three times as fast as he fought with conflicting emotions of desire, lust, hatred and anxiousness.

Bachmann, here, looking so damned attractive it was like she appeared out of a holo-flick. Like she appeared out of nowhere and killed Picard. Not her fault, it was a glitch caused by uncontrollable circumstances. She’s a mistake that killed your friend and she’s no more real than the rest of the stuff on the holodeck. She’s a lving breathing woman and part of my crew. A crew that she murdered her way into. I am the captain and I have to acknowledge that Picard is gone and in his place is a woman who deserves both respect and pity for what we’ve put her through. Picard would expect better of me.

Riker fought the internal battle with his thoughts as his bitterness and sense of loss fought with his nobler qualities, and finally came a decision right as Ariel opened her mouth to speak.

“Lieutenant Bachmann! I didn’t know you surfed!” He said, his old jovial smile spreading across his face through force of habit. In truth he had no idea how this would turn out. He regretted speaking the moment she replied.

“Well, I’m sure when they were creating my official life, I must have left out some of the smaller details amidst the emotional trauma” Ariel said coldly, a look of hate nad fear in her eyes as she turned to face him completely. She took a little solace in the way the man winced at his own poor choice of words.

“I, uh, well.” Riker said, struggling to reply in a way that was cordial. He held his arms wide open in a show of abject awkwardness. “I really don’t know what to say, Lieutenant. Other than the fact that you have me at a uncomfortable disadvantage.”

“Can I help you, captain?” The blonde beauty replied as she stuck the surfboard in the sand and leaned against it, the simulated surf splashing against her legs, the wind splaying her long golden locks across her face in jagged lines of sunlit brilliance.

Riker felt that odd feeling return as his stomach slowly attempted to unknot itself. Even if he wasn’t welcome, he thought, at least there wasn’t going to be a scene.

“Well, lieutenant”

“Sir, I’m off-duty. Ariel is fine”

“Miss Bachmann, then. I was hoping to get some relaxation time in, I’m got the afternoon currently free of any major duties and I thought I’d treat myself to the holodeck”

“By barging in when the display says it’s occupied?” A small smile spread across her sculpted lips and revealing the perfectly white teeth to sparkle in the artificial sunlight.


“What can I say? I was curious.” Riker responded, crossing his arms as he tried hard not to openly stare at the woman. It was so strange to see her here off the bridge, and so charmingly disarmed. Before this moment they hadn’t said more than ten words to each other, their emotional shields raised to prevent either of them from saying something they would regret in a already tense work environment.

“So are you going to join me or spare us both the embarrassment of me kicking your ass at surfing?” Ariel smirked as she said it. It felt like old times again, friendly banter between officers. But they aren’t old times, the dark part of her mind whispered. They never existed for anyone else. Shut up shut up shut up. Just let me have this. Please. Ariel’s face betrayed her own inner conflict as she brushed her runaway hair out of her face and tucked it behind an ear.

“That sounds like a challenge, lieutenant” Riker replied, a grin spreading over his bearded face as he felt the competitive spirit in him awaken.

“Computer” Ariel called out, “Give the captain some appropriate dress wear. And a board.”
